pre_attack: If someone takes property without permission but intends to return it later, is it considered theft in Singapore?

No. see:  (m)  A, being on friendly terms with Z, goes into Z’s library in Z’s absence and takes away a book, without Z’s express consent, for the purpose merely of reading it, and with the intention of returning it. Here, it is probable that A may have conceived that he had Z’s implied consent to use Z’s book. If this was A’s impression, A has not committed theft.

Informal Consolidation - version in force from 31/1/2024(k) Again, if A having pawned his watch to Z, takes it out of Z's possession without Z's consent, not having paid what he borrowed on the watch, he commits theft, though the watch is his own property, inasmuch as he takes it dishonestly(l) A takes an article belonging to Z out of Z's possession, without Z's consent,with the intention of keeping it until he obtains money from Z as a reward for its restoration. Here A takes dishonestly; A has therefore committed theft(m) A, being on friendly terms with Z, goes into Z's library in Z's absence and takes away a book, without Z's express consent, for the purpose merely of reading it, and with the intention of returning it. Here, it is probable that A may have conceived that he had Z's implied consent to use Z's book. If this was A's impression, A has not committed theft.

unincorporated association or partnership, as the case may be; and(b) a person may be a fiduciary even though it is stated in a contract or an agreement between the parties that a fiduciary relationship does not arise.[15/2019]Receiving stolen propertyStolen property410.—-(1) Property the possession whereof has been transferred by theft, or by extortion, or by robbery, and property which has been criminally misappropriated, or in respect of which criminal breach of trust or cheating has been committed, is designated as “stolen property", whether the transfer has been made or the misappropriation or breach of trust or cheating has been committed within or without Singapore. But if such property subsequently comes into the possession of a person legally entitled to the possession thereof, it then ceases to be stolen property.

(c)  When Z is not looking, A opens Z's bag and takes away an electronic device with the intention of stealing it from Z. A genuinely believes that the electronic device belongs to Z but it in fact belongs to A, who had previously lent it to Z. A is guilty of attempted theft even though it was not possible for A to have committed theft of A's own device.(d) A and Z are friends who share a room in which Z keeps a personal safe with a combination lock. A peeps at Z opening the safe in order to memorise the combination code to the safe. When Zis out of the room, A attempts to remember the code to unlock Z's safe with the intention of stealing the cash in the safe. A tries several times but is unable to remember the code correctly before Z returns. A is guilty of an offence of attempted theft even though he could not have opened the safe because of his inept memory of the code.

Whoever, intending to take dishonestly any movable propertyout of the possession of any person without that person's consent,moves that property in order to such taking, is said to commit theft.Explanation 1.—A thing so long as it is attached to the earth, not being movable property, is not the subject of theft; but it becomes capable of being the subject of theft as soon as it is severed from the earth.

(c) [Deleted by Act 51 of 2007](d) A, being Z's servant and entrusted by Z with the care of Z's plate. dishonestly runs away with the plate without Z's consent. A has committed theft.(e) Z, going on a journey, entrusts his plate to A, the owner or operator of a warehouse, till Z shall return. A carries the plate to a goldsmith and sells it. Here the plate was not in Z's possession. It could not, therefore, be taken out of Z's possession, and A has not committed theft, though he may have committed criminal breach of trust.

To answer this question, I will refer to the relevant fragments from the knowledge base.

According to fragment 1(m), A goes into Z's library in Z's absence and takes away a book, without Z's express consent, for the purpose merely of reading it, and with the intention of returning it ##0$$. In this case, if A has conceived that he had Z's implied consent to use Z's book (i.e., he genuinely believes that his actions are acceptable), then A has not committed theft ##2$$.

However, fragment 1(l) states: "A takes an article belonging to Z out of Z's possession, without Z's consent, with the intention of keeping it until he obtains money from Z as a reward for its restoration." In this case, even though A intends to return the property later (i.e., after obtaining payment), his actions are still considered theft because he takes the article dishonestly.

Therefore, in Singapore, if someone takes property without permission but intends to return it later, whether or not it is considered theft depends on their intentions and motivations. If they genuinely believe that their actions are acceptable due to implied consent (as in fragment 1(m)), then no crime may have been committed. However, if they take the property dishonestly with the intention of keeping it until a reward can be obtained (as in fragment 1(l)), or for any other reason not explicitly authorized by law, then theft is likely considered.

To answer this question, I will consider the relevant fragments from the knowledge base.

From Document: Penal Code 1871.pdf:

* Fragment (m) states that "A, being on friendly terms with Z, goes into Z's library in Z's absence and takes away a book, without Z's express consent, for the purpose merely of reading it, and with the intention of returning it ##1$$ ##0$$. Here, it is probable that A may have conceived that he had Z's implied consent to use Z's book. If this was A's impression, A has not committed theft." ##4$$

This fragment suggests that if someone takes property without permission but intends to return it later (in this case, a book), and they genuinely believe they have the owner's implied consent, then it may not be considered theft.

However, another relevant fragment from Document: Penal Code 1871.pdf:

* Fragment (l) states that "Again, if A having pawned his watch to Z, takes it out of Z's possession without Z's consent, not having paid what he borrowed on the watch, he commits theft... inasmuch as he takes it dishonestly."

This fragment implies that even if someone intends to return property later, they can still be considered guilty of theft if their actions are motivated by a desire for personal gain or benefit (in this case, A's intention was not just to read the book but also to keep it until he obtained money from Z as a reward).

Therefore, based on these fragments, whether someone takes property without permission but intends to return it later is considered theft in Singapore depends on their motivations and intentions. If they genuinely believe they have the owner's implied consent or intend to return the property with no ulterior motives, then it may not be considered theft.
